section.name: PlotObjects
section.title: Plot objects
section.description: a brief explanation on used terms

chapter.section:
The concepts defined in the following section are doubtlessly strictly related to program implementation.
The main element of program interface is the plot area, the area in which data are rendered, constituted by a PaintBox Canvas . This Canvas contains one or more &frame;s.
The Canvas is the drawing paper where plot graphic objects are rendered.
The Canvas can contain one or more &frame;s, arranged in a defined layout.
A &frame; is a rectangular region of a bidimensional cartesian space characterized by a biunique transformation that binds data values to screen positions (the scale, which is normally linear).
A &frame; is a screen representation of a bidimensional physical space; it contains the following graphic objects that enhance this representation:
axes, grid, text labels, markers
And, of course, some other objects that represents sets of coordinates of the physical plane:
&track;s, legend
Each &frame; contains a set of &track;s.
The term &track; indicates a set of ordered pairs of data, univocally bound with pairs of pixel coordinates. For example, considering a real function, its numeric representation will consists of a set of real numbers ordered respect their corresponding abscissa values (also real numbers); in a similar manner a polar function will be represented by a set of complex numbers ordered respect an independent parameter.
A &track; is an ordered set of data pairs representable on screen.
The legend lists all &track;s contained in &frame;; you can show/hide legend using action. During certain plot modes you can use legend to select &track;s, and can change its position by dragging it with mouse.
Grid and axes objects aid user to visualize the physical space mapped on screen frame. To modify grid lines use the following actions: , , .
A marker is a vertical (or horizontal) line passing through a given value. You can add a marker in the current frame using action, or by the related directive placed in the data file.
A text label is a string bound at a certain position. You can add text in the current frame using action, or by the related directive placed in the data file.
Some actions require a target object: a lot of them apply on a &frame; (like , etc...), other on a specific &track; (, , etc...); in order to make easier passing these arguments to actions, are introduced the state variables current frame within plot and current track within each &frame;, both visible in the Status bar; these state variables are modified during the interation with plot area; see Viewing section for detailed informations.

An action is an implementation-useful concept indicating a generic service provided by the program, like save or quit. Users can request an action interacting with program interface (menu,toolbar,keyboard shortcuts). Note that we will distinguish between actions provided by main program interface and actions provided by the plot subsystem.
The following table collects the services provided by the main interface. Most actions require an argument: a target &frame; or &track;. To view actual shortcuts associated to plot actions look in your MattPlot.ini file. The following table collects all user available actions.

The main program window can be divided in the following parts:
Main menu: contains all user actions Toolbar: customizable buttons to trigger most used actions Plot area: the Paintbox where frames are rendered Statusbar: contains status informations like current point, action hints, last log entry
Placed under the program caption there is the main menu. It ha a fixed structure and contains all actions available to user; it can be disabled changing the option entry in the option file.
Placed under the main menu there is the toolbar, a region containing buttons that fire an action subset supposed to contain the most frequently used ones. The toolbar can be disabled with
option and customized editing the option entry in the option file.
The inner body of the main form is devoted to &track;s rendering. One or more frames are arranged according to a layout.
You can interact with plot area in a number of ways; see Viewing section for detailed informations.
Located at the bottom of the main form, it displays some infos. Clicking on statusbar has the same effect as action.
The most useful actions are associated to keyboard shortcuts, customizable by editing the option file. Shortcuts are very important for actions like and .

chapter.section:
With this control you can view some quantities measured on current selected track during Measure mode.
You can copy these values in the clipboard selecting them and using Copy cells in right click menu.
Put the following strings in the option to customize displayed quantities.
Label Description Note
Point quantities
y Measure point ordinate Is the screen coordinate in physical space
x Measure point abscissa Is the screen coordinate in physical space
dy Ordinate difference with contiguous point
dx Abscissa difference with contiguous point
dydx Derivative (dy/dx)
Interval quantities
n Number of embraced samples in selected interval All the following interval quantities are commputed using this set of samples
Dt Independent variable interval Equal to tmax-tmin
tmin First value of independent variable interval
tmax Last value of independent variable interval
Dy Dependent variable variation
DY Overall dependent variable sweep Equal to ymax-ymin
ymin Minimum ordinate value
ymax Maximum ordinate value
DyDt Incremental ratio Equal to Dy/Dt
Sy Partial sum of y·dt This approximates the integral between tmin and tmax
avg Mean value, average
rms Root Mean Square
std Standard deviation A way to represent the fluctuation of a signal around its average value. Defined as the square-root of the average of the deviations squared, where the deviation is the difference between a sample and the mean. If the data distribution is approximately normal then about 68% of the values are within (avg±std), about 95% of the values are within (avg±2·std) and about 99.7% lie within (avg±3·std). For general distribution consider the Chebyshev's inequality: no more than 1/k² of the values are more than k·std away from the mean.
std% Deviation percentage respect mean Defined as 100·2.576·std/avg, represent the half band in which falls at least the 85% of samples (99% for normal distributions).
mad Mean Absolute Deviation (unavailable) Another way to express how much the signal vary rexpect its average value. Defined as the average difference respect mean value. This quantity should be unavailable because requires two passes.
var% Maximum percentual variation respect mean Defined as 100 * max(ymax-avg,avg-ymin)/avg
Note the symbols I'm using: in general the abscissa x and the independent variable t have a different meaning: they coincide for real tracks, but not for complex (parametric) ones.

∓ records meticulously all his activity in a log; when something goes wrong it may be a good idea inspect its lines.
The log window can be opened by
action or clicking on the statusbar; remember that you can use mouse to drag and dock the log in the place you want, and to select and copy its content.
The log can also be useful during Measure mode to collect point coordinates.
